plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation,
an agency shall complete a written report that includes
all the following information:
(c) Dates and places of contacts, names of persons
interviewed, and names of the interviewers. If children
are interviewed, their last names may not be included in
the report.
Two of two special evaluations reviewed included the foster child’s first and last names
in the special evaluation report.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service plans
for each child and parent or parents, as follows:
• (b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial
removal and at least once every 90
calendar days thereafter.
2

Three of six foster children case records were reviewed, one was late with the
updated service plan.
Repeat Violation Established
2023 Renewal, CAP Approved 8/9/2023
FOM Policy – 722-06B Family Team Meeting: Practice Guidance
Documentation
The DHS 1105, Family Team Meeting Report, is
used to capture family demographics, FTM
logistical information, needs, strengths, action
any recommendations made for the family
during the FTM. The DHS-1105, Family Team
Meeting Report, must be completed for every
FTM.
Three of six foster child records reviewed did not have documentation of an
FTM 1105 as required.
Repeat Violation Established
2023 Renewal, CAP Approved 8/9/2023
FOM POLICY 722-08D TREATMENT PLANS – AGREEMENT AND
Signatures.
Once completed and approved the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
Caseworker, Supervisor, second line supervisor, when
siblings in care are place apart, parents who are a
member of a participating household. Youth ages 14
and older. Foster parents, relative caregivers, and
unrelated court -ordered caregivers. Parents/legal
guardians, youth, and caregivers must check yes or no
for the when signing the treatment plan: I have
participated in the Development of the case service
plan and Parent Agency Treatment Plan.
Two of six case records reviewed showed a PATP being signed late by the youth and
the foster parent.

VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with the individual CAP is as follows:
The CAP submitted was in response to the 2023 renewal inspection and was
approved on 7/11/2023 and the CAP was approved on 8/9/2023. The CAP
addressed 5 violations. There was improvement with two of the violations that
was cited in the 2023 renewal inspection. However, during this licensing period 3
of the violations that were cited in the 2023 renewal inspection are repeats for this
year indicating additional corrective action planning is needed this year with the
repeat violations.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Director when interviewed and in her Chief Administrator Assessment (CAA)
discussed how the agency continued to experience massive turnover until October
2023 and whereby the supervisors were carrying cases. She stated new workers
being hired into the agency provided the supervisors the opportunity to transition
cases to the new workers and the agency began to experience stability. The
director discussed how the agency continued to be impacted by previous months
due to the managers and supervisors having increased duties when the agency
was understaffed. She stated the managers and supervisors continued to work
towards ensuring the children remained in safe, stable placements while
permanency was achieved. The director complemented the in – house trainings
on strengthening their skill sets, building competency and improving knowledge of
their program and procedures to improve stability within the agency. She stated
the director of operations continues to provide the managers and leaders in a
concerted effort to build programing, mentoring, coaching and training staff.
4

Financial Overview
The agency’s certified independent auditor’s report dated September 30, 2023,
and 2022 and the agency annual financial budget report was reviewed. There
were no financial concerns identified.
Staff Interviews
The staff members interviewed stated their coworkers were supportive and are
helpful with current assignments. The staff members were all consistent in stating
they would like more on the job training after CWTI. The staff members feel the
agency provides trainings, but they would like to have more in-depth in-house
trainings and communication among their supervisors and leaders. The staff
stated they would like a more comprehensive training program as well as
communication among supervisors and managers so that the staff can gain
retention and remain in their roles.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency has adequate space and equipment to complete required
responsibilities. Files and CHRI are stored securely in a manner that prevent
unauthorized access within metal locked cabinets and drawers and behind locked
doors.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no safety concerns identified by the DCWL Analyst.
5

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
